lines.text: Enter BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: Statilius show'd the torch-light, but, my lord, He came not back: he is or ta'en or slain.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Sit thee down, Clitus: slaying is the word; It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.
Whispers

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Peace then! no words.

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: I'll rather kill myself.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Hark thee, Dardanius.
Whispers

lines.speaker: dardanius
lines.text: Shall I do such a deed?

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: O Dardanius!

lines.speaker: dardanius
lines.text: O Clitus!

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

lines.speaker: dardanius
lines.text: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: Now is that noble vessel full of grief, That it runs over even at his eyes.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Come hither, good Volumnius; list a word.

lines.speaker: volumnius
lines.text: What says my lord?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why, this, Volumnius: The ghost of Caesar hath appear'd to me Two several times by night; at Sardis once, And, this last night, here in Philippi fields: I know my hour is come.

lines.speaker: volumnius
lines.text: Not so, my lord.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius. Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes; Our enemies have beat us to the pit: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves, Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius, Thou know'st that we two went to school together: Even for that our love of old, I prithee, Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.
Low alarums

lines.speaker: volumnius
lines.text: That's not an office for a friend, my lord.
Alarum still

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: Fly, fly, my lord; there is no tarrying here.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Farewell to you; and you; and you, Volumnius. Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep; Farewell to thee too, Strato. Countrymen, My heart doth joy that yet in all my life I found no man but he was true to me. I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto. So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue Hath almost ended his life's history: Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest, That have but labour'd to attain this hour. Alarum. Cry within, 'Fly, fly, fly!'

lines.speaker: clitus
lines.text: Fly, my lord, fly.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Hence! I will follow. I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord: Thou art a fellow of a good respect; Thy life hath had some smatch of honour in it: Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face, While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?
Exeunt CLITUS, DARDANIUS, and VOLUMNIUS

lines.speaker: strato
lines.text: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Farewell, good Strato. Caesar, now be still: I kill'd not thee with half so good a will.
Runs on his sword
Dies
Alarum. Retreat. Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, LUCILIUS, and the army

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: What man is that?

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: My master's man. Strato, where is thy master?

lines.speaker: strato
lines.text: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala: The conquerors can but make a fire of him; For Brutus only overcame himself, And no man else hath honour by his death.

lines.speaker: lucilius
lines.text: So Brutus should be found. I thank thee, Brutus, That thou hast proved Lucilius' saying true.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them. Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

lines.speaker: strato
lines.text: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Do so, good Messala.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: How died my master, Strato?

lines.speaker: strato
lines.text: I held the sword, and he did run on it.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Octavius, then take him to follow thee, That did the latest service to my master.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: This was the noblest Roman of them all: All the conspirators save only he Did that they did in envy of great Caesar; He only, in a general honest thought And common good to all, made one of them. His life was gentle, and the elements So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world 'This was a man!'

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: According to his virtue let us use him, With all respect and rites of burial. Within my tent his bones to-night shall lie, Most like a soldier, order'd honourably. So call the field to rest; and let's away, To part the glories of this happy day.
Exeunt
